p: Variability due to either phenotypic plasticity or genetic strain diversity is documented as a contributing factor to competition for three nonindigenous aquatic plant species of the Great Lakes region. Genetic variability in nonindigenous populations of Impatiens glandulifera have been documented to contribute to its ability to adapt to local environments within a few generations [ 164]. Frangula alnus demonstrates a high degree of phenotypic plasticity in bud burst timing [ 165]. Solanum dulcamara shows phenotypic plasticity with regard to height, leaf morphology, and chlorophyll production in accordance with environmental conditions (light, temperature, and water) [ 166, 167, 168, 169].
